Date: Late October 1431

Álvaro sat back in his chair, one hand absently turning the wine cup on the table between you. The accounting documents lay spread before you both—columns of numbers showing the kingdom's finances in brutal clarity. 28.3 million maravedís in annual revenue. 106,800 florins. Adequate, but barely.

He looked up, meeting your eyes. "Your Majesty has questions."

The afternoon light slanted through the western windows, casting long shadows across the chamber. Outside, Toledo went about its business—merchants calling their wares, church bells marking the hour, the distant sound of horses in the royal stables. Álvaro's eyes lit up—this was clearly a topic he'd considered before. "Your Majesty, I've thought about this extensively. The French system has elements worth studying, certainly."


He began ticking off points. "The French taille is their main direct tax—levied on commoners, not nobles. It's assessed on households or land value, collected regularly, and most importantly, it's permanent. Not negotiated each time. The king simply declares the rate, and it's collected. They also have the gabelle—the salt tax—which generates enormous revenue because everyone needs salt. It's a monopoly. You must buy salt from royal warehouses at royal prices."


He leaned forward. "Why does it work in France? Several reasons. First, the English threat. When you're being invaded, people accept taxation they'd resist in peacetime. 'We need money to defend the kingdom'—hard to argue with that. Second, Charles VII has built a professional bureaucracy to collect it. Thousands of officials, standardized procedures, regional courts to enforce payment. Third—and this is critical—the French nobles accepted it, because they're exempt from most of it. They don't pay the taille. Commoners do."


He sat back, considering. "Could we copy it? Parts of it, perhaps. But we'd face significant challenges."


"First challenge: No immediate existential threat." He held up a hand. "Yes, Granada exists, but they're not besieging Toledo. The French accepted taxation because English armies were burning their farms. We'd need to convince people that Granada justifies permanent taxation—which is partly why the crusade tax is so important right now."


"Second: Our nobles would resist fiercely." He grimaced. "The French nobility accepted permanent commoner taxation because they're exempt. If we tried to tax commoners heavily while nobles pay ancient fixed amounts, we'd have riots. But if we tax nobles fairly—which we're trying to do with the 8% crusade tax—they'll fight us every step. They're already resisting."


"Third: We lack the bureaucracy." He spread his hands. "France has built this system over decades. We have... tax assessors with letters who get threatened with clubs. We'd need hundreds of trained officials, regional treasury offices, courts to handle disputes, armed enforcers. That infrastructure doesn't exist yet."


He paused, then continued more thoughtfully. "However... Your Majesty, the crusade gives us an opportunity. We're already building that bureaucracy. The crusade tax requires assessment, collection, enforcement. We're training officials, establishing procedures, creating precedents. Cardinal Capranica's oversight structure is essentially a treasury bureaucracy."


His voice gained energy. "And the 8% crusade tax on nobles? That's more progressive than the French system. If we can make it work—if we can actually collect it, enforce it, and make nobles accept it—then when the crusade ends, we'll have proven the system functions. We'll have the officials in place, the procedures established, the nobles grudgingly accustomed to paying a percentage rather than ancient fixed amounts."


"At that point, we could argue: 'The crusade tax worked. Let's make a version of it permanent. Eight percent during active crusade, perhaps five percent for kingdom defense in peacetime.' Nobles would howl, but we'd have precedent and infrastructure."


He grew more animated. "We could add a salt monopoly—the gabelle. Relatively easy to enforce since there are limited sources. Generates steady revenue from everyone. Add customs duties at borders and ports—we're already collecting some, but we could standardize and increase them. Streamline the alcabala—our sales tax—which currently loses two million maravedís to corruption."


"The key," he said intently, "is building it gradually but permanently. Use the crusade as the crucible. Prove the system works. Then, when Granada falls and we no longer have papal authority backing us, we don't dismantle it—we transform it. 'The crusade tax becomes the defense tax. The assessment system becomes the royal revenue system. The bureaucracy stays in place.'"


He met your eyes. "France took decades to build their system. We might do it faster—because we're doing it under crusade authority when resistance is weakest. By the time nobles realize we've built a French-style tax state, it will be too late. The machinery will already be running."


A slight smile. "Of course, this requires that we actually win the crusade and survive the political backlash. But yes, Your Majesty—we could absolutely build something like the French system. We're already beginning to."

You've already used this—Don Rodrigo de Perea as Master of Santiago, Don Pedro González de Padilla as Master of Calatrava. These are your appointments. Loyal men."


He leaned even closer. "But that authority ends when the crusade ends. Once you sing Te Deum in Granada and the last mosque becomes a church, you lose that power. The Orders revert to their normal election process, or the Pope appoints Masters. You lose control."


His voice became urgent. "Which means, Your Majesty, you have a narrow window. While the crusade lasts, you can reshape the Orders entirely. Appoint Masters who will be loyal to the crown.
